H1.body:
ardha, as, a1, am, half, halved, forming a half
[cf. Osset. ardag]; ardha ardha, one part, the other
part; (as, am), m. n. the half; one part of two, a
part, a party; half; a short syllable. The accent is
on the last syllable. (Ardha may be compounded in
a peculiar way with an ordinal, e. g. ardha-tr2iti1ya,
containing (two and) the third (only) half, i. e. two
and a half; ardha-c4aturtha, three and a half, &c.)
--Ardha-ka1la or ardha-ku1t2a, as, m. an epithet
of S4iva. --Ardha-kr2ita, as, a1, am, half-done, half-
performed. --Ardha-ketu, us, m., N. of a Rudra.
--Ardha-kot2i1, f. half a crore, five millions. --Ar-
dha-kosha, as, m. a moiety of one's treasure.
--Ardha-kros4a, as, m. half a league. --Ardha-
kha1ra, am, i1, n. f. a measure, half a kha1ri1. --Ardha-
gan4ga1, f., N. of the river Ka1veri1. --Ardha-garbha,
as, a1, am, Ved. in the middle of the womb. --Ar-
dha-guc4c4ha, as, m. a necklace of twenty-four
strings. --Ardha-gola, as, m. a hemisphere. --Ar-
dha-c4akravartin or ardha-c4akrin, i1, m. half a
c4akravartin; N. of the nine black Va1sudevas and the
nine enemies of Vishn2u. --Ardha-c4andra, as, m.
half-moon; the semicircular marks on a peacock's
tail; the semicircular scratch of the finger nail; an
arrow, the head of which is like a half-moon; the
hand bent into a semicircle or the shape of a claw, as
for the purpose of seizing or clutching abything; (a1),
f., N. of the plant Convolvulus Torpethum; (as, a1,
am), crescent-shaped, of a semilunar form. --Ardha-
c4andra1ka1ra (ºra-a1kº), as, a1, am, or ardha-
c4andra1kr2iti, is, is, i, half-moon-shaped, crescent-
shaped; (as), m. or (is), f. a meniscus. --Ardha-
c4andrika1, f., N. of a climbing plant. --Ardha-
c4olaka, as, m. a short bodice. --Ardha-ja1hnavi1, f.,
N. of the river Ka1veri1. --Ardha-tanu, us, f. half a
body. --Ardha-tikta, as, m., N. of a plant. --Ar-
dha-tu1ra, as, m. a particular kind of musical instru-
ment. --Ardha-dagdha, as, a1, am, half-burnt.
--Ardha-divasa, as, m. half a day, midday; a
day containing one half of a whole day, a day of
twelve hours. --Ardha-deva, as, m., Ved. demi-god.
--Ardha-dha1ra, am, n. a knife or lancet with a
single edge, the blade two inches long, the handle six.
--Ardha-na1ra1yan2a, as, m. a form of Vishn2u.
--Ardha-na1ri1s4a (ºri1-i1s4a), as, m. one of the forms
of S4iva (half male and half female). --Ardha-na1va,
am, n. half a boat. --Ardha-nis4a1, f. midnight. --Ar-
dha-pan3c4a1s4at, f. twenty-five. --Ardha-pan2a, am,
n. a measure containing half a pan2a. --Ardha-patha,
am, n. half-way; (e), ind. midway. --Ardha-pa1dika,
as, a1, am, having only half a foot. --Ardha-pa1ra1-
vata, as, m. a kind of pigeon. --Ardha-pula1yita, am,
n. a half-gallop, canter. --Ardha-pu1rn2a, as, a1, am,
half-full. --Ardha-prahara, as, m. half a watch, one
hour and a half. --Ardha-br2ihati1, f., Ved. half the
usual breadth. --Ardha-bha1ga, as, m. a half; a
part. --Ardha-bha1gika, as, i1, am, or ardha-bha1-
gin, i1, ini1, i, taking or sharing half. --Ardha-bha1j,
k, k, k, taking or sharing half; (k), m. a sharer,
companion. --Ardha-bha1skjara, as, m. midday.
--Ardha-bhot2ika, f. a kind of cake. --Ardha-ma1-
gadhi1, f. a variety of the Ma1gadhi1 dialect. --Ardha-
ma1n2ava or ardha-ma1n2avaka, as, m. a necklace of
twelve strings. --Ardha-ma1tra1, f. half a short sylla- [Page0084-c+ 79]
ble. --Ardha-ma1rge, ind. half-way, midway. --Ar-
dha-ma1sa, as, m. half a month; ardhama1sa-s4as,
ind. every half month, or fortnight. --Ardhama1sa-
tama, as, a1, am, or ardhama1sika, as, a1, am,
done or happening every half month; lasting half
a month, or a fortnight. --Ardha-musht2i, is, m. f.
a half-clenched hand. --Ardha-ya1ma, as, m. half a
watch, an hour and a half. --Ardha-ratha, as, m.
a warrior who fights on a car along with another.
--Ardha-ra1tra, as, m. midnight; a night contain-
ing half a whole day of twenty-four hours. --Ardha-
ra1tra-samaya, as, m. the time of midnight. --Ar-
dhara1tra1rdhadivasa (ºra1tra-ardhaº), am, n. the
equinox. --Ardharc4a (ºdha-r2ic4a), as, am, m. n.
half a verse or hemistich. --Ardharc4a-s4as, ind. in
every hemistich. --Ardha-vastra-sam2vi1ta, as, a1,
am, clothed or enveloped in half-garments. --Ardha-
visarga, as, m. the sound Visarga before k, kh, p,
ph, so called because its sign (Z) is the half of that
of Visarga (H). --Ardha-vi1kshan2a, am, n. a side-
look, a glance, a leer. --Ardha-vr2iddha, as, a1, am,
middle-aged. --Ardha-vaina1s4ika, as, m., N. of the
followers of Kan2a1da (‘arguing half-perishableness’).
--Ardha-vya1sa, as, m. the radius of a circle.
--Ardha-s4ata, am, n. fifty; one hundred and
fifty. --Ardhas4ana, am, for ardha1s4ana (ºdha-
as4º), am, n. half a meal. --Ardha-s4aphara, as,
m. a kind of fish. --Ardha-s4abda, as, a1, am, hav-
ing a low voice. --Ardha-s4esha or ardha1vas4esha
(ºdha-avº), as, a1, am, having only half left. --Ar-
dha1s4ya1ma, as, a1, am, half-clouded. --Ardha-
s4loka, as, m. half a S4loka. --Ardha-san3ja1ta-s4asya,
as, a1, am, having its crops half-grown. --Ardha-
si1rin, i1, m. a cultivator, a ploughman, who takes
half the crop for his labour. --Ardha-ha1ra, as,
m. a necklace of sixty-four or of forty strings. --Ar-
dha-hrasva, am, n. half a short syllable. --Ar-
dha1n6s4a (ºdha-an6º), as, m. a half, the half. --Ar-
dha1n6s4in (ºdha-an6º),i1, ini1, i, sharing a half. --Ardha1-
ka1ra (ºdha-aº), as, m. half the letter a; another
name for avagraha, q. v. --Ardha1n4ga (ºdha-an4º),
am, n. half the body. --Ardha1rdha (ºdha-arº),
as, m. half of a half, a quarter; half and half. --Ar-
dha1vabhedaka (ºdha-avº), as, m. pain in half the
head, hemicrania; (am), n. dividing in equal parts.
--Ardha1vas4esha (ºdha-avº), as, a1, am, having
only one half left. --Ardha1s4ana (ºdha-as4º), am,
n. half a meal. --Ardha1sana (ºdha-a1sº), am, n.
half a seat (it is considered a mark of high respect to
make room for a guest on the same seat with one's
self); greeting kindly or with respect; exemption
from censure. --Ardhendu (ºdha-inº), us, m. a half-
moon or crescent; the semicircular impression of a
finger nail; an arrow with a crescent-shaped head;
the hand expanded in a semicircular from like a claw.
--Ardhendu-mauli (ºdha-inº), is, m. S4iva, whose
diadem is a half-moon. --Ardhendra (ºdha-inº),
as, a1, am, that of which a half belongs to Indra.
--Ardhokta (ºdha-ukº), as, a1, am, half-uttered, said
imperfectly or indistinctly. --Ardhokti (ºdha-ukº),
is, f. speaking indistinctly or incompletely, broken
or interrupted speech. --Ardhodaya (ºdha-udº),
as, m. the rising of the half-moon. --Ardhodita
(ºdha-udº), as, a1, am (rt. i with ud), half-risen;
(rt. vad), half-uttered. --Ardhoruka (ºdha-u1ru),
as, a1, am, reaching to the middle of the thighs;
(am), n. a short petticoat.

osht2ha, as, m. (contracted fr. ava-
stha), the down-hanging lip, i. e. the upper lip (op-
posed to adhara), a lip in general; osht2hau or
dva1v osht2hau, du. the lips, the two lips; (i1), f. a
creeper bearing a red flower, to which the lip is com-
monly compared (Coccinia Grandis); [cf. bimba:
cf. also Slav. u10sta, neut. pl.; u10stna, f.: Lat. ostium.]
In compounds a final a or a1 before osht2ha may be
optionally dropped (e. g. bimba + osht2ha becomes
either bimbosht2ha or bimbausht2ha, ‘red-lipped,’
and the fem. of the comp. adj. may be formed in a1
or i1). --Osht2ha-karn2aka, a1s, m. pl., N. of a fabu-
lous race who have their ears and lips very near
each other. --Osht2ha-kopa or osht2ha-prakopa, as,
m. a disease of the lips. --Osht2ha-ja, as, a1, am,
produced by the lips, labial. --Osht2ha-ja1ha, am, n.
the root of the ear. --Osht2ha-pallava, am, n. a lip
or the lips. --Osht2ha-put2a, am, n. the cavity made
by opening the lips. --Osht2ha-pushpa, am, n. the
plant Pentaptera Tomentosa. --Osht2ha-roga, as,
m. any morbid affection of the lips. --Osht2ha1dhara
(ºt2ha-adhº), au, du. or am, n. the upper and lower
lip. --Osht2hopama-phala1 (ºt2ha-upama1-phº), f. the
creeper Bryonia Grandis, whose flower resembles
a lip.

tri, trayas m. pl., tisras f. pl., tri1n2i
n. pl. (said to be fr. rt. tr2i1; in Ved. tri1 occurs for
tri1n2i and tri1n2a1m for traya1n2a1m), three; [cf. Gr.
Zend thri,
thri-tya, thris: Lat. tres, tri-a, ter-tiu-s, ter:
Goth. threis, thriya, thri-dya: Angl. Sax. threo,
thry, thri: Slav. triye, tre-tii, ‘third:’ Lith. try4s,
‘three;’ tre4-c4za-s, ‘third:’ to tisras belong Old
Hib. teora, Cambro-Brit. f. tair, Armor. teir.]
--Tri-kakud, t, t, t, having three peaks or points
or horns &c.; (t), m., N. of a mountain in the
Hima1laya [cf. tri-ku1t2a and su-vela]; an epithet of
Kr2ishn2a or Vishn2u; N. of a son of S4uc4i and father
of Dharma-sa1rathi; a kind of ritual observance; the
highest, chief. --Tri-kakuda, as, a1, am, having
three peaks or humps &c. --Tri-kakubh, p, p, p,
Ved. having three peaks or points; an epithet of
Indra's thunderbolt or of Indra himself; (p), m., N.
of a mountain; a kind of ritual observance; [cf. tri-
kakud.] --Tri-kat2a, as, m., N. of a plant (Ruellia
Longifolia), = go-kshuraka; [cf. tri-kan2t2a.] --Tri-
kat2u, u, n. or tri-kat2uka, am, n. the aggregate of
three spices, viz. black and long pepper and dry
ginger; [cf. kat2u-traya.] --Tri-kan2t2a, am, n. the
three thorny plants, a collective N. of three kinds of
Solanum, viz. br2ihati1, agni-damani1, and duh2-
spars4a1; (as, a1, am), having three thorns; (as),
m., N. of a plant, = go-kshuraka or pattra-gupta;
a kind of fish. --Tri-kan2t2aka, as, m., N. of a
plant, = go-kshuraka; a kind of poisonous insect;
a kind of fish (Silurus); a kind of weapon. --Tri-
kadruka, a1s, m. pl., Ved. probably a N. of three
peculiar Soma-vessels [cf. kadru], or perhaps a N.
of an oblation consisting of three offerings of the
Soma (which is of a dark-brown colour); the first
three days of the Abhi-plava festival which lasts six
days, (respectively called Jyotis, Go, and A1yus.)
--Trikadruki1ya, as, a1, am, containing the word
tri-kadruka. --Tri-karn2a, as, i1, am, having
three ears. --Tri-karman, (at the beginning of a
comp.) the three chief duties of a Bra1hman, viz.
sacrifice, study of the Vedas, and liberality (e. g. tri-
karma-kr2it, performing these three duties); (a1, a1,
a), engaging in these three actions. --Tri-karsha,
am, n. = tri-ka1rshika. --Tri-kala1, f., N. of a female
deity produced by the union of three gods for
the destruction of Andhaka. --Tri-ka1n2d2a, as, a1, [Page0388-c+ 81]
am, consisting of three parts or divisions; forty-
eight cubits long; (as or am), m. or n. (?), a work
consisting of three parts, especially the dictionary of
Amara-sin6ha, also called Amara-kosha. --Trika1n2d2a-
c4inta1-man2i, is, m. or trika1n2d2a-viveka, as, m., N.
of commentaries on this work. --Trika1n2d2a-man-
dana, N. of a work. --Trika1n2d2a-s4esha, as, m. a
vocabulary in three chapters supplementary to the
Amara-kosha by Purushottama. --Tri-ka1ya, as, a1,
am, having three bodies; (as), m., N. of Buddha or of
a Buddha. --Tri-ka1rshika, am, n. the three contracting
(ka1rshika fr. rt. kr2ish) substances, dry ginger, Ati-
visha1, and Musta1; [cf. tri-karsha, danta-karshan2a.]
--Tri-ka1la, am, n. the three times, viz. past,
present, and future time; morning, noon, and
evening; the present, past, and future tenses of a
verb; (am), ind. three times, thrice; (as, a1, am),
connected with or relating to the three times (past,
present, and future). --Trika1la-jn3a, as, a1, am,
knowing the three times, omniscient; (as), m. a
divine sage; a deity; a N. of Buddha, the founder of
the Buddhist religion. --Trika1la-dars4in, i1, ini1, i, see-
ing (or knowing) the past, present, and future, omni-
scient; (i1), m. a R2ishi or divine sage; N. of Buddha.
--Trika1la-vid, t, t, t, knowing the three times; (t),
m. a Buddha; (with Jainas) an Arhat. --Tri-kun2d2i1-
s4vara (ºd2a-i1s4º?), am, n., N. of a Tantra. --Tri-
ku1t2a, as, a1, am, having three peaks or humps or
elevations &c.; (as), m., N. of several mountains,
= tri-kakud and su-vela; a mountain in Ceylon
on the top of which Lan4ka1, the capital of Ra1van2a,
was situated; (am), n. sea-salt prepared by evapo-
ration. --Triku1t2a-lavan2a, am, n. a peculiar kind
of salt (= dron2i1-lavan2a). --Triku1t2a-vat, a1n, m., N.
of a mountain. --Tri-ku1rc4aka, am, n. a sort of
knife with three edges. --Trikaika (ºka-eka), Ved.,
N. of an Eka1ha; [cf. eka-trika.] --Tri-kon2a, as, a1,
am (borrowed fr. the Gr. ), triangular,
forming a triangle; (as, a1), m. f. Trapa Bispinosa;
(am), n. (in astron.) N. of the fifth and ninth
mansion [cf. tri-kona-bhavana and tri-trikon2a];
the vulva; [cf. tri-bhuj.] --Trikon2a-kun2d2a, am,
n., N. of a mystical vessel in the form of a diagram.
--Trikon2a-phala, am, n. Trapa Bispinosa. --Tri-
kon2a-bhavana, am, n. (in astron.) N. of the fifth
and ninth mansion. --Tri-krama, as, m. (according
to the Pra1tis4a1khyas) a Krama word composed of three
words or members, the middle one of which is a single
vowel. --Tri-ksha1ra, am, n. the three burning or
acrid substances, viz. natron, saltpetre, and borax.
--Tri-kshura, N. of a plant, = kokila1ksha. --Tri-
kha, am, n. a cucumber (‘having three cavities’).
--Tri-khat2va, am, i1, n. f. three beds collectively.
--Tri-khan2d2a, the earth as divided into three por-
tions. --Tri-kharva, a1s, m. pl., Ved., N. of a particu-
lar school of theologians. --Tri-gan4ga, am, n., N.
of a Ti1rtha; [cf. sapta-gan4ga.] --Tri-gan2a, as,
m. the aggregate of the three objects of existence,
viz. virtue (dharma), pleasure or the ‘dulce’ (ka1ma),
and wealth or the ‘utile’ (artha); [cf. tri-varga.]
--Tri-gata, as, a1, am, tripled; gone or done in three
ways; (am), n. the expression of different senses by the
same word. --Tri-gandhaka, am, n. = tri-ja1taka,
--Tri-gambhi1ra, see under gabhi1ra. --Tri-garta,
a1s, m. pl., N. of a people inhabiting the modern
Lahore; (as), m. a prince of the Tri-gartas; the
country of the Tri-gartas; a particular method of
calculation; (a1), f. a lascivious woman, a wanton;
a woman in general; a kind of cricket (= ghur-
guri1, ghurgurika1); a pearl. --Trigartaka, a1s,
m. pl. = tri-garta. --Trigarta-ra1ja, as, and tri-
garta-ra1jan, a1, m. king of Tri-garta. --Tri-gar-
tika, as, m. the country of the Tri-gartas. --Tri-
gun2a, a1s, m. pl. the three qualities or constituents
of nature and every existing thing, i. e. sat-tva,
rajas, and tamas; (as, a1, am), consisting of three
threads or strings; threefold, three times repeated,
thrice, triple, treble (e. g. sapta trigun2a1ni dina1ni,
three times seven days); containing the three Gun2as
or properties; (am), ind. in three ways, three times,
thrice. --Trigun2a1-karn2a, as, i1, am, whose ears [Page0389-a+ 81]
have two slits dividing them into three parts (as a
mark of distinction). --Trigun2a1-kr2ita, as, a1, am,
thrice ploughed (a field &c.). --Tri-gra1mi1, f. an
assemblage of three villages, N. of a place. --Tri-
gra1hin, i1, in2i1, i, extending to the length of three
(padya1s). --Tri-c4akshus, us, m. ‘triocular,’ ‘three-
eyed,’ an epithet of Kr2ishn2a (more properly of S4iva).
--Tri-c4atuh2-karn2a, the third and fourth hypo-
tenuses. --Tri-c4atura, a1s, a1s, a1n2i, pl. three or
four. --Tri-c4aturdas4a, au, &c., du. the thir-
teenth and fourteenth. --Tric4atva1rin6s4a, as, i1, am
(fr. the next), the forty-third. --Tri-c4atva1rin6s4at,
t, f. forty-three. --Tri-c4aritra (?), am, n. three
kinds of characters, (perhaps a wrong reading for
stri1-c4aritra; cf. tri-gu1d2ha.) --Tri-c4it, t, t, t, con-
sisting of three layers or seats of sacrificial grass.
--Tri-c4i1vara, am, n. the three vestments of the
Buddhist ascetic. --Trijagaj-janani1, f. the mother of
the three worlds, an epithet of Pa1rvati1. --Tri-jagat,
t, n. or tri-jagati1, f. the triple world, i. e. heaven,
the intermediate region, and earth, or heaven, earth,
and the lowerworld. --Trijagan-mohini1, f. confound-
ing the minds of the (inhabitants of the) three worlds,
a form of Durga1 (?). --Tri-jat2a, as, a1, am, wearing
three braids of hair; (as), m. an epithet of S4iva;
N. of a Bra1hman; (a1), f., N. of a Ra1kshasi1 who
was friendly to Si1ta1; N. of a tree, = vilva, Ægle
Marmelos. --Trijat2a1-svapna-dars4ana, am, n. ‘the
dream of Tri-jat2a1,’ N. of a chapter in the fifth book
of the Ra1ma1yan2a. --Tri-ja1ta or tri-ja1taka, am, n.
three spices collectively, viz. mace, cardamoms, and
Laurus Cassia (cinnamon). --Tri-ji1va1, f. the sine
of three signs or ninety degrees, a radius. --Tri-
jya1, f. = the preceding. --Tri-n2ata, as, a1, am (fr.
tri-nata), bent in three places, epithet of a bow;
(a1), f. a bow; [cf. tr2in2ata1.] --Tri-n2ayana, as, m.
[cf. tri-nayana], ‘three-eyed,’ an epithet of S4iva.
--Tri-n2avan or tri-n2ava (fr. tri+navan), consisting
of three times nine or twenty-seven parts, connected
with the Tri-n2ava Stoma; three times nine, i. e. twenty-
seven; trin2ava-sa1hasra, twenty-seven thousand; [cf.
tri-saptan.] --Tri-n2a1c4iketa, as, a1, am, one who
has thrice kindled the fire called Na1c4iketa; (as),
m. an epithet of Na1ra1yan2a (perhaps as worshipped
with this fire); (according to Kullu1ka Bhat2t2a on
Manu III. 185, tri-n2a1c4iketa means either ‘a part
of the Adhvaryu or Yajur-veda,’ or ‘a vow connected
with it,’ or ‘one who performs this vow.’) --Tri-
n2a1man, a1, a1, a, Ved. having three names, epithet
of a deity, perhaps of Agni. --Tri-n2i1ta1, f. a wife,
(‘thrice married,’ according to the belief that a girl
belongs to Soma, Gandharva and Agni, before she
obtains a human husband.) --Tri-taksha, am, i1, n. f.
(fr. tri-takshan), an association of three carpenters.
--Tri-tas, ind. on three sides, from every side. --Tri-
ta1, f. or tri-tva, am, n. a triad, a trinity, an assemblage
of three. --Tri-trikon2a, am, n. (in astronomy) N. of
the ninth mansion; [cf. tri-kon2a and trikon2a-bha-
vana.] --Tri-dan2d2a, am, n. the three staves of a
mendicant Bra1hman who has resigned the world,
(these staves are tied together so as to form one);
triple subjection of words, thoughts, and acts; the
state of a religious ascetic; (i1), f., N. of a literary
work. --Tri-dan2d2aka, am, n. the three staves of a
mendicant Bra1hman described above. --Tridan2d2a-
dha1ran2a, am, n. carrying three staves tied together.
--Tri-dan2d2in, i1, m. a wandering mendicant or
devotee who has resigned worldly pursuits and carries
three long bamboo staves tied together in his right
hand; the religious man who has obtained a com-
mand over his words, thoughts, and actions, or mind,
body, and speech; [cf. eka-dan2d2in.] --Tri-dat, an,
ati1, at, having three teeth. --Tri-dala1, f. a creeping
plant, Cissus Pedata. --Tri-dalika1 or (according to
some) tri-da1lika1, f., N. of a plant, = c4arma-kasha1.
--Tri-das4a, a1s, m. pl. (fr. tri-das4an), three times
ten, i. e. thirty; the three times ten or thirty
deities, i. e. in round numbers a N. for the thirty-
three deities, not including Brahma1, Vishn2u, and
S4iva, viz. the twelve A1dityas, eight Vasus, eleven
Rudras, and two As4vins; (as, a1, am), divine; (as), [Page0389-b+ 81]
m. a god, a deity, an immortal; (am), n. the
